Text saved: "Power distance" is a way to talk about how people see bosses and workers.
In a "high power distance" place, bosses are very strong. Workers must listen to them.
In a "low power distance" place, bosses and workers are more equal.

Gabriela worked in an old job.
Her job had a high power distance culture.
This means bosses had a lot of power.
Everyone knew their place.
Leaders made all the big choices.
People did not often ask them questions.

But Gabriela's team was from Sweden.
They worked in a low power distance culture.
This means bosses and workers often worked together.
They found answers and made choices together.
In Sweden, leaders were like teachers.
They wanted workers to have their own ideas.
They wanted workers to ask them questions.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL
